prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Instrumental setup: The main goal of this project is to robustly detect clumpy HCO+ (4–3) emission in the central regions of a sample of 7 local luminous infrared galaxies. In addition, we will also observe the CO (3–2) line and the dust continuum at ~ 860?m. Therefore we request Band 7 with ALMA in extended array configuration at an angular resolution of 0.15”, which will allow us to resolve structures on scales of 50–100pc at the distance to our galaxies. A single pointing will be enough to measure the line flux in the desired nuclear area (~500 kpc). The recoverable angular scale is much larger than the expected sizes of the line-emitting clumps and therefore no ACA observations are needed. The spectral windows are selected to encompass the CO (3–2) 345.8 GHz and HCO+ (4–3) 356.7 GHz lines, although they have not been defined to be centered on them. This configuration optimizes the spectral range covered by the 2 side-bands. Each spectral window has a bandwidth of 1875 MHz and a spectral resolution of ~ 7.8 MHz (~7 km s-1). The required spectral resolution, though, is 20 km s-1, enough to achieve the goals of this proposal.
Sensitivity requirements: Herschel/SPIRE observations of IRASF01417+1651 give a 3-sigma upper limit of 1.8?10-17 W m-2 on the CO (4–3) flux. However, it is detected in the (6–5) transition. Based on the observed CO ratios of other warm LIRGs similar to IRASF01417+1651 (Lu et al. 2014, in prep), we estimate that the CO (4–3) transition should have been detected at a level of ~ 0.9?10-17 W m-2. We assume a factor of 0.5 for the CO (3–2) / CO (4–3) ratio (Carilli et al. 2013) and a factor of 0.05 for the HCO+ (4–3) / CO (4–3) ratio (Wilson et al. 2008). The expected fluxes for these two lines are 0.42x10-17 and 0.42x10-18 W m-2, respectively. The HCO+ (4–3) line is the most faint of the features we want to observe and therefore it is the one on which the requested sensitivities are based. Although we cannot predict the exact spatial distribution of the dense molecular gas - in fact this is the goal of this proposal, we know from observations of other LIRGs and ULIRGs in the GOALS sample (Sakamoto et al. 2010, Imanishi et al. 2013, Xu et al. 2013) that a significant fraction of the molecular gas visible to ALMA will be in clumps or a small scale circum-nuclear disk. We therefore assume that approximately 50% of the flux is within the central ~1". We have assumed a width for the lines of 300 km s-1 and we request a frequency width of ~20 km s-1, enough to resolve the gas motion in the expected rotating disks and clumps. When calculating the sensitivities, we require to detect the HCO+ (4–3) line at a S/N = 20. The CO (3–2) and the continuum emission will be detected at much larger S/N (> 100). The requested sensitivity for IRASF01417+1651 is 0.6mJy, yielding a total observing time of 1.68h, including overheads (42min on-source).

Although we cannot predict the exact spatial distribution of the dense molecular gas - in fact this is the goal of this proposal, we know from observations of other LIRGs and ULIRGs in the GOALS sample (Sakamoto et al. 2010, Imanishi et al. 2013, Xu et al. 2013) that a significant fraction of the molecular gas visible to ALMA will be in clumps or a small scale circum-nuclear disk. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The goal of this project is to pinpoint the location and measure the compactness of the dense molecular gas in the central kpc of 7 nearby luminous infrared (IR) galaxies selected to span a wide range of conditions of the interstellar medium (ISM) as probed by the [CII]158μm line to far-IR (FIR) continuum ratio. To this end, we request Band 7 ALMA observations of the HCO+(J=4–3) and CO(J=3–2) molecular gas lines as well as of the 860μm dust continuum. By comparing the HCO+ and CO luminosities and morphologies we will be able to quantify the fraction of dense molecular gas and measure its distribution as a function of the [CII] deficit. Being able to access the distribution of the molecular gas as well as the cold dust on scales ≤ 100pc will allows us to test the scenario in which LIRGs with low [CII]/FIR ratios and large kpc-scale IR-luminosity surface densities also show more compact individual star-forming regions. This will provide an important link between the variations of the [CII]/FIR ratio observed in local LIRGs and the spatial configuration of their dense molecular gas content, key for interpreting the results obtained from high-z SF galaxies detected in [CII] with ALMA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Spitzer Science Center, California Institute of Technology
